Short answer, yes. The first question is what the feminist movement is actually about. Why does everyone need to become ‘feminist'? It is hard to see what feminism actually stands for through all the noise and fuzz. In its radical form (and it appears that the movement is getting more and more radical), feminism rejects any ‘male' value. This polarised form of debating will unfortunately not move the discussion forward. Second question is if the feminist movement should be seen as a means for a higher objective or as a goal as such. Unfortunately, the latter view seems to have won it from the first. The feminist movement has turned into a movement that embraces the call for ‘more women' or ‘more female values' as such, without even critically assessing why these would be needed. Even the women that refer to feminism as a means to achieve higher societal needs seem to fail in conveying their ideas in a nuanced way. Firstly, they refer to feminism as a matter of fairness: society needs more women because women used to be discriminated in the past (and yes it is mostly a question of the past in Western societies as the ‘pay gap' and other illustrations are way less striking if one dares to analyse the figures with intellectual honesty instead of a call for attention). Is it fair though to project the previous discrimination of women by the previous generation on the current generation of men (e.g. why do women need special executive training programmes in companies; why do companies need to hire more women, especially in overly politically correct institutions such as international organisations)? Secondly, women claim to justify feminism by reasons of accepting diversity. Creating a more diverse society is a valid reason to pursue, but does the current feminist movement stay true to this value? It rather seems that feminists put the fight for women's rights at a higher pedestal than other categories of diversity. Does the radical call for feminism imply that the fight for women is of a superior nature compared to for instance the fight for equal recognition of black males? In addition, any radical form of ‘equality' paradoxically undermines diversity. Demanding that everyone becomes a feminist, neglects that men and women are fundamentally different and that their different traits deserve to be respected. It is shameful and sad to see how many people try to surf on the hype of feminism simply because they see that any opinion in a newspaper on embracing feminism in a radical and overly politically correct fashion will immediately give them the attention they are desperately seeking for. With particular reference to the politicians of the European Commission, who recently voted in favour of a women to become the next president of the European Commission i.a. because she is a women (indeed not only because she is a women but it was one of the criteria), I would like to say: what is the goal of the European Union for the next years? To solve the problem of its people or to become the worldwide centre of political correctness? This radical yet sad example only illustrates that politicians will follow any hype that gives them attention. By embracing any feminist initiative without even talking about substance, politicians curb the attention of the real problems people are dealing with such as less jobs, jobs taken over by robots, geopolitical tensions, trade wars etc. The debate on feminism - or rather the lack of it - only shows the polarised world we are living in. Instead of depicting anyone who dares to challenge the feminist movement as anti-feminine per se, one would better focus all of its energy on coming up with the important debate on how men AND women can both contribute to creating a better world. For a more nuance view on the subject, also check: [LINK]

commentThread.commentText: Yes

Decent debate. We need more of these discussions. It's easy to say "yes it has" but the reasons why are important. The panel touched on a good point that confuses men and confuses the entire conversation. What kind of equality is it that the feminist movement desires? Ought we to have "men's" newspapers and "women's" newspapers, or not? Are we distinct markets with different interests, or are we fundamentally the same? It seems to me that feminists are just as confused on these questions as everyone else. But feminism's method seems to be attempting to have their cake and eat it too. They want women's newspapers but they also want 'regular' newspapers to have a balanced and diverse voice that speaks to everyone. It begs the question of how they really feel about our equality. It seems that instead of some established and well-defined notion of equality, what feminism wants is anything that benefits women. As long as that confusion and lack of definition exists, feminism will be at risk of making claims or proposals that go "too far." The phrase "too far" can mean several things in this context. In my evaluation, too far includes anything that is a denial of science, that creates a hierarchical status of women over men, and anything that is unrelated to the rights and privileges of women. Again, these issues only arise because everyone is still confused as to what equality should be; feminism has not provided a clear and concise definition of equality. As such, they'll sometimes try to deny biology with the aim to increase "equality." For example: trying to get transgender women the right to fight other women in MMA matches, despite any science that says that should not be allowed on the basis of biology. That is feminism going too far. Secondly, the sick days for period pains is one issue where some men feel that it is giving women special privileges, ones denied to men. Personally I don't see it as an issue, but it's an example of how "equality" may be denied for the sake of benefiting women. Another example of how feminism may go too far. Lastly, feminism can go too far when it overreaches. That is, when it makes an issue unrelated to rights and privileges into a "feminist issue" or a women's issue. For example: "manspreading" is apparently a women's issue. Feminism claims that the male gender is prone to spreading their legs wide, taking up unnecessary space, and this is a form of microaggression toward women, implying that the man is more worthy of space and attention, implying that men are dominant and women are submissive. When in reality, it's not abou t sexism or the removing of rights and privileges, rather it's an issue of rude people that take up too much space. Whether it's a man with his legs, a women with her purse, or a child with their toys, people taking up space unnecessarily is not a feminist issue. This sort of overreaching into both mundane and serious matters, is another way that feminism can go too far. In conclusion, a lot of these problems could be avoided if feminism or society at large could agree on exactly what kind of equality we want, what is reasonable expectations for ea ch gender given our biologies, and what exactly is a women's issue as opposed to a general issue. This lack of clarity and lack of definition is what makes this conversation so difficult, confusing, and unproductive. Feminism was a lot easier to support when it was very clear about it's goals regarding equal rights and privileges under the law for all peoples. As long as feminism remains confused and as a result denies biology, asks for special privileges, and overreaches, you'll find many people saying that feminism has gone too far.
